title: Pest Control Documentation
description: Comprehensive documentation requirements for pest control programs including program scope, contracts, operator licenses, insurance, monitoring records, and corrective action documentation

requirements.text: Is the pest control program properly documented, detailing the scope of the program, target pests and frequency of checks, including a copy of the contract with the extermination company (if used), Pest Control Operator license(s)/training (if baits are used), and insurance documents?
requirements.question: Is the pest control program properly documented, detailing the scope of the program, target pests and frequency of checks, including a copy of the contract with the extermination company (if used), Pest Control Operator license(s)/training (if baits are used), and insurance documents?
mandatoryStatements: Pest control program must be properly documented detailing scope, target pests, and monitoring frequencies
Documentation must include copies of extermination contracts when external services are used
Current Pest Control Operator licenses/training certificates and insurance documents must be maintained
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review pest control program documentation including the written program describing scope, target pests, and inspection frequencies. When external pest control services are used, contracts should be on file. For operations using pesticide baits, Pest Control Operator licenses or training documentation must be current. Insurance certificates should be current and provide adequate coverage for pest control activities.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain complete pest control documentation that is reviewed annually or when the program changes. Contract renewals, license expiration dates, and insurance coverage should be tracked to ensure continuity. Program scope should be reviewed when pest activity trends indicate changes are needed.

requirements.text: Is there a schematic drawing/plan of the facility showing numbered locations of all pest monitoring devices (e.g., rodent traps, bait stations, insect light traps, etc.) both inside and outside the facility?
requirements.question: Is there a schematic drawing/plan of the facility showing numbered locations of all pest monitoring devices (e.g., rodent traps, bait stations, insect light traps, etc.) both inside and outside the facility?
mandatoryStatements: A schematic drawing must show numbered locations of all pest monitoring devices inside and outside the facility
Device locations must include rodent traps, bait stations, insect light traps, and all other monitoring equipment
Schematic must be current and updated when device locations change or new devices are added
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the facility schematic to confirm it shows all pest monitoring device locations with unique identifying numbers for rodent traps, bait stations, insect light traps, glue boards, and any other pest monitoring equipment. The schematic should cover both interior and exterior areas with sufficient detail to locate each device during inspections.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain current facility schematics showing pest monitoring device locations that are used during pest control inspections to ensure all devices are checked. Schematics should be updated when devices are relocated, added, or removed, with changes communicated to all personnel conducting pest control activities.

requirements.text: Are service reports created for pest control checks detailing inspection records, application records, and corrective actions of issues noted (in-house and/or contract)?
requirements.question: Are service reports created for pest control checks detailing inspection records, application records, and corrective actions of issues noted (in-house and/or contract)?
mandatoryStatements: Service reports must be created for all pest control checks whether conducted in-house or by contractors
Reports must detail inspection findings, any pesticide or control measure applications, and corrective actions taken
Documentation must be sufficient to demonstrate program effectiveness and response to identified issues
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review pest control service reports to confirm they document inspection findings for all monitored locations, record any pest activity detected, detail pesticide or control measure applications with products and quantities used, and describe corrective actions taken to address identified issues. Reports should be dated, signed, and maintained for all inspection events.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should ensure service reports are completed for every pest control inspection with documentation showing trends in pest activity over time. Reports should be reviewed by management to verify corrective actions are adequate and timely, with escalation procedures when persistent pest activity indicates program deficiencies.

capaInject: Implement immediate corrective actions when pest activity is detected including targeted treatment and structural repairs to eliminate entry points
Establish procedures for addressing gaps in pest control operator licensing, insurance documentation, or contract compliance
Develop action plans for updating pest monitoring device locations when facility layout changes or new risk areas are identified
Create preventive measures for high-risk areas identified through pest monitoring trends including enhanced sanitation protocols
Implement verification procedures to ensure pest control service reports document all required inspection findings and corrective actions
traceabilityInject: Maintain pest control program documentation including scope, target pests, monitoring frequencies, and copies of extermination contracts
Keep current Pest Control Operator licenses, training certifications, and insurance documents with expiration date tracking
Retain schematic drawings showing numbered locations of all pest monitoring devices both inside and outside the facility
Archive pest control service reports documenting inspection records, application records, and corrective actions with dates and signatures

micro_inject: Rodent activity introduces Salmonella, Leptospira, and other pathogens through fecal contamination of food contact surfaces and ingredients
Insect infestations including flies and cockroaches mechanically transfer pathogenic bacteria from waste areas to food processing zones
Birds nesting in or near facilities shed Salmonella, Campylobacter, and E. coli through droppings contaminating ventilation systems and outdoor processing areas
Inadequate pest control allows pests to damage packaging and protective barriers exposing products to microbial contamination
Pest harborage areas with poor sanitation create reservoirs of pathogenic microorganisms that continuously recontaminate cleaned food processing environments
